Welcome to articlo’s documentation!#

Introduction#

Articlo is a web application designed for searching and managing scientific articles. This documentation provides a guide on how to use the application and its features.

Administrator Guide#

Overview#

Articlo administrators have additional capabilities for managing users, moderators, and uploading articles. This guide covers those functionalities.

Managing Moderators#

Administrators can add, remove, or modify moderators.

User Guide#

Overview#

Articlo allows authenticated users to search for and save scientific articles. Here’s a guide on how to use the application.

Searching for Articles#

To search for articles, follow these steps:

  1. Log in to your account.

  2. Use the search bar to enter keywords.

  3. Filter results based on various criteria.

  4. Save favorite articles for later reference.

Methods Documentation#

Utils Methods:#

backendapp.utils.clean_text(text)#

Clean the extracted text by removing unwanted symbols, formatting, and lines matching specific patterns.

Parameters:

text (str) – The text to be cleaned.

Returns:

The cleaned text.

Return type:

str

backendapp.utils.column_boxes(page, footer_margin=0, no_image_text=True)#

Return a list of column bounding boxes for the given page.

Parameters:

  • page (fitz.Page) – The PyMuPDF (fitz) page object.

  • footer_margin (int) – The margin to exclude from the bottom of the page for detecting columns. Default is 0.

  • no_image_text (bool) – Flag to exclude text within images from column detection. Default is True.

Returns:

A list of bounding boxes representing columns on the page.

Return type:

list

backendapp.utils.delete_article_from_elastic(article_id)#

Delete an article from Elasticsearch by its ID.

Parameters:

article_id (str) – The ID of the article to delete.

Returns:

True if the article is successfully deleted, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

backendapp.utils.download_pdf_from_url(url)#

Download a PDF file from a given URL and return the file object.

Parameters:

url (str) – The URL of the PDF file.

Returns:

BytesIO object containing the PDF file if successful, None otherwise.

Return type:

BytesIO or None

Raises:

ValueError – If no PDF link is found on the page or if the content type is unsupported.

backendapp.utils.extract_article_info(text, first_pages, last_pages)#

Extract information from an article including title, authors, institutions, abstract, keywords, references, and date.

Parameters:

  • text (str) – The full text of the article.

  • first_pages (str) – Text from the first pages of the article.

  • last_pages (str) – Text from the last pages of the article.

Returns:

A dictionary containing extracted information.

Return type:

dict

backendapp.utils.extract_pdf_metadata(file)#

Extract metadata from a PDF file.

Parameters:

file (BytesIO or bytes) – The PDF file content as either a BytesIO object or raw bytes.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the extracted metadata. Keys include ‘Title’, ‘Authors’, ‘CreationDate’, ‘Abstract’, and ‘Keywords’.

Return type:

dict

Raises:

ValueError – If the provided file format is not supported.

backendapp.utils.extract_text_from_pdf(file, num_pages=2)#

Extract and organize text from a PDF file considering multi-column layout.

Parameters:

  • file (BytesIO or bytes) – The PDF file content as either a BytesIO object or raw bytes.

  • num_pages (int) – The number of pages to extract from the beginning and end. Default is 2.

Returns:

Three strings representing the full text, text of the first num_pages pages, and text of the last num_pages pages.

Return type:

tuple

backendapp.utils.is_email(text)#

Check if the given text resembles an email address.

Parameters:

text (str) – The text to be checked.

Returns:

True if the text resembles an email address, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

backendapp.utils.is_valid_scientific_pdf(file)#

Check if the given PDF file meets the criteria for a scientific article.

Parameters:

file_path (str) – The path of the PDF file to be checked.

Returns:

True if the PDF is a valid scientific article, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

backendapp.utils.parse_and_validate_date(date_string)#

Parse and validate a date string.

Parameters:

date_string (str) – The date string to be parsed.

Returns:

A formatted date string in YYYY-MM-DD format if parsing is successful, or None if the parsing fails.

Return type:

str or None

backendapp.utils.parse_metadata_date(date_string)#

Parse a date string extracted from metadata and return it in YYYY-MM-DD format.

Parameters:

date_string (str) – The date string extracted from metadata.

Returns:

A formatted date string in YYYY-MM-DD format if parsing is successful, or None if the parsing fails or the input is None.

Return type:

str or None

backendapp.utils.send_to_elasticsearch(index_name, data)#

Sends data to Elasticsearch.

Parameters:

  • index_name (str) – The name of the index.

  • data (dict) – The data to be sent.

backendapp.utils.update_article_in_elastic(article_id, updated_fields)#

Update an article in Elasticsearch.

Parameters:

  • article_id (str) – The ID of the article to update.

  • updated_fields (dict) – Dictionary containing the updated fields and their values.

Returns:

True if the article is successfully updated, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

backendapp.utils.upload_article_process(file)#

Process the uploaded PDF file, extract metadata, validate, extract text, perform analysis, and return the article data.

Parameters:

file – The uploaded PDF file.

Returns:

Article data dictionary containing information extracted from the PDF.

Return type:

list of dict
